questions.text: The third week of development is characterized by the appearance of the branchial apparatus, the embryonic primordium from which head and neck structures will be derived. Which of the following structures develop from the second pharyngeal arch?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ The posterior digastric muscle is derived from the second branchial arch and thus is innervated by its nerve, the facial (Seventh cranial) nerve. The anterior digastric muscle is derived from the first branchial arch and is innervated by its nerve, the mandibular division of the trigeminal (fifth cranial) nerve. The posterior cricoarytenoideus muscle and the superior constrictor muscle,derived from a combination of the fourth and sixth branchial arches, are innervated by the vagus (tenth cranial) nerve. The stylopharyngeus is derived from the third branchial arch and is the only voluntary muscle innervated by the glossopharyngeal (ninth cranial) nerve.
  • ↳ The posterior digastric muscle is derived from the second branchial arch and thus is innervated by its nerve, the facial (Seventh cranial) nerve.
  • ↳ The anterior digastric muscle is derived from the first branchial arch and is innervated by its nerve, the mandibular division of the trigeminal (fifth cranial) nerve.
  • ↳ The posterior cricoarytenoideus muscle and the superior constrictor muscle,derived from a combination of the fourth and sixth branchial arches, are innervated by the vagus (tenth cranial) nerve.
  • ↳ The stylopharyngeus is derived from the third branchial arch and is the only voluntary muscle innervated by the glossopharyngeal (ninth cranial) nerve.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman complains of headache and dizziness after hitting a cabinet door with her head. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan and venogram show a large blood clot in the great cerebral vein of Galen. The obstructed vein of the brain is a direct tributary of which of the following venous structures?

An elderly patient reports muscle weakness and lethargy. A urine specimen reveals a sodium concentration of 600 mmol/L and osmolality of 1200mosm/L. Additional lab tests revels the following:- Plasma Na+ concentration = 167mmol/L Plasma renin activity = 4ng/mL/h (normal = 1/mL/h) Plasma ADH = 60pg/mL (normal = 3pg/mL) Plasma aldosterone = 15ng/dL (normal = 6pg/dL) What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s hypernatremia?

options.label: A
options.text: Dehydration caused by decreased fluid intake

options.label: B
options.text: Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of ADH

questions.correct_answer: A. Dehydration caused by decreased fluid intake

questions.text: For a sensory nerve fibre that is connected to the Pacinian corpuscle located on the palmar surface of the right hand, the synaptic connection with the subsequent neuron is in which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Right dorsal column nucleus in medulla

options.label: B
options.text: Left dorsal column nucleus in medulla

options.label: C
options.text: Dorsal horn on right side of spinal cord

options.label: D
options.text: Dorsal horn on left side of spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: A. Right dorsal column nucleus in medulla

questions.text: A 6 year old child presents with history of fever with chills and rigor for past two days. He was prescribed antimalarial “primaquine” along with other symptomatic therapy. After 4 days child presents again with loss of appetite yellow discoloration of sclera. Attending physician suspected glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency in the child, which was responsible for hemolytic episode in this child after exposure to primaquine. Which of the following statement is true about G6PD enzyme

options.label: A
options.text: It is the enzyme belonging to class II of enzyme classification

options.label: B
options.text: It is the enzyme deficient in Von Gierke disease

options.label: C
options.text: It is the enzyme of oxidative phase of Pentose phosphate pathway

options.label: D
options.text: This enzyme needs NAD+ as cofactor

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the enzyme of oxidative phase of Pentose phosphate pathway

questions.text: A 65 year old male who was unwell for past few weeks came for consultation. He complained of pain abdomen, vomiting and headache from the last 2 days. History of loss of appetite, weakness, malaise and nausea for a week was there. He gives the history of yellow discolouration of eyes, urine was also turning deep yellow but the stools were clay colored. There was no history of any fever, drug intake, alcoholism or any other problem. On physical examination the patient was found to be undernourished. Yellow discoloration of skin, sclera, and palate was observed. The vitals were normal. Gall bladder was palpable. Liver was enlarged and tender. Spleen was normal.

A 35 year old male has presented to physician for refractory microcytic hypochromic anemia. He has been on oral iron on and off for few years now. The patients mother had breast carcinoma and similar physical appearance as the patient. General physical examination is as shown in the image. Blood examination shows occult blood positive. Serum ferritin is 45 m g/L and iron is 50 m g/dL. Which of the following is the correct interpretation and management in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Pigmentation is due to oral iron thus start parenteral iron

options.label: B
options.text: Patient is has developed iron overload start Chelation therapy.

options.label: C
options.text: Suspicious of a familial cancer syndrome do PTEN mutation tests

options.label: D
options.text: Suspicious of familial cancer syndrome do SKT 11 mutation tests

questions.correct_answer: D. Suspicious of familial cancer syndrome do SKT 11 mutation tests

questions.text: A 30 year old male on treatment for depression has presented to psychiatrist with having jerky involuntary movements. The psychiatrist changes the anti-depressant and asks for a follow up 1 month later. The patient has more aggravated involuntary jerky moments now is also having difficulty in swallowing, thus was referred to neurologist for opinion. Family history suggests his mother and his paternal uncle had depression later developed dementia and died at the age of 45 and 46 respectively. Further family history suggests that his maternal cousin has also developed jerky movements and had depression and died at the age of 38. Now the neurologist is suspecting a genetic disease in this patient, which of the following genetic mutation is likely to be seen in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: An amplification of APP gene on 21st chromosome

options.label: D
options.text: A Robertsonian translocation between toe 21 chromosomes.

questions.correct_answer: C. An amplification of CAG repeats

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman had Goodpasture syndrome which progressed to chronic renal failure. She is 165 cm tall and weighs 55 kg. She now has blood pressure measurements in the range of 150/90 to 180/110 mm Hg, but does not regularly take medications. Laboratory studies show her blood urea nitrogen is over 100 mg/dL and she requires chronic dialysis. A chest x-ray shows an enlarged heart. The size of her heart is most likely to be the result of which of the following processes involving the myocardial fibers?

A surgeon is examining the wound on day 5 after an appendectomy in a 45 year old diabetic male. The sutured site from outside appears clean with no obvious signs of infection. On deep palpation of the wound there is tenderness, the wound is soft and a clear fluid coming out of the wound. Which of the following is the correct inference and management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Healing is normal: Go ahead with suture removal on day 8

options.label: D
options.text: Infected wound: send for culture & sensitivity of the oozed fluid.

questions.correct_answer: C. Delayed healing: delay suture removal

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with a severe middle ear infection comes to a hospital. On examination, a physician finds that the infection has injured the tympanic nerve. The damaged nerve:

options.label: A
options.text: Is a branch of the facial nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Synapses with fibers in the lesser petrosal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.correct_answer: D. Is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: A 43-year-old man has new onset of difficulty with speaking. Examination reveals problems in elevating the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth, secondary to paralysis of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved?
Which nerve lesion could produce the condition where stimulation of right cornea results in blinking of the left eye but not the right eye?

A patient complains of persistent numbness of the chin, lower lip and lower teeth. She further indicates that she has difficulty in chewing. Radiographic studies of the head demonstrate a small discrete mass in the infratemporal fossa. Which nerve has been compromised by the mass ?

Cognitive stimuli such as reading, problem solving, and talking all result in increase in cerebral blood flow. Which of the following changes in cerebral tissue concentration is NOT likely to increase cerebral blood flow?

A 55- year old woman has a serum potassium of 6mEq/L and a serum sodium of 150mEq/L. Which of the following set of changes best describes the Nernst potential of K + and resting membrane potential (RMP) in a typical neuron in this woman compared to normal? (Assume normal intracellular ion concentrations).

options.label: A
options.text: No change K+ Nernst potential, no change in RMP

options.label: B
options.text: Less negative K+ Nernst potential, no change in RMP

options.label: C
options.text: No change in K+ Nernst potential, less negative RMP

options.label: D

questions.text: A 60- year-old man has an ECG at a local hospital after having presented to the Emergency following a motorbike accident. His weight is 80kgs, and his bp is 160/90 mm Hg. The QRS voltage was 0.5 millivolt in lead I and 1.5millivolt in lead III. What is the QRS voltage in lead II?

A 70-year-old man who has been smoking 30 cigarettes per day for the last 50 years presents with shortness of breath. The patient is diagnosed with pulmonary emphysema. Which of the following set of changes is present in this patient as compared to a healthy individual?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased pulmonary compliance, increased elastic recoil

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased pulmonary compliance, decreased elastic recoil

options.label: C
options.text: Increased pulmonary compliance, decreased elastic recoil

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased pulmonary compliance, increased elastic recoil

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased pulmonary compliance, decreased elastic recoil

questions.text: A 17 year old male is admitted to medicine department with history of bizzare behaviour, episodes of crying. On examination he had tremors in hand, incoordinated limb movements, dysarthria and dysphagia was observed. On examination his eyes showed golden brown ring around corneal rim. Following were biochemical findings: Serum ceruloplamin: 12 mg/dl( normal level is 18-35 mg/dl) Copper content in liver(biopsy): 300 µ g/g of tissue( normal level is 20-50 µ g/g) Urinary copper(24 hr collection): 270 µ g(normal is 20-50 µ g) Which statement is correct regarding disease?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This patient is suffering with Wilson’s disease which is autosomal recessive disorder, caused by mutation of ATP 7B gene which encodes membranous copper transporting ATPase.
  • • The defect in biliary secretion of copper results in excess copper accumulation in liver and toxicity of liver. Level of ceruloplasmin in serum is low due to lack of incorporation of copper to apo ceruloplasmin. As the disease advances, free copper in plasma is increased which is deposited in brain and eye resulting in neurological and psychiatric disorder, and Kayser-Fleischer ring around the cornea. KF ring is visible by naked eye and slit lamp examination may be needed to confirm the ring.
  • • Zinc is main line of treatment which not only block the intestinal absorption of copper, it also stimulates the synthesis of metallothionine in the liver which binds the copper in nontoxic form and reduced its toxicity. Penicillamine was used earlier as copper chelator but presently trientine is preferred over penicillamine because of its lesser toxicity.

questions.text: A 25-month-old Caucasian girl has coarse facial features and gingival hyperplasia and, at 2 months of age, began developing multiple, progressive symptoms of mental retardation, joint contractures, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly. Levels of lysosomal enzymes are elevated in her serum, and fibroblasts show phase-dense inclusions in the cytoplasm. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most consistent with these observations?

14 year old boy presents with easy fatigue and yellow discoloration of sclera. On investigation total bilirubin was 6.5 mg/dl with indirect portion being 4.8 mg/dl. Peripheral smear shows hemolytic picture. Enzyme assay reveled deficiency of pyruvate kinase. Which of the following condition is true regarding this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: ATP level in reticulocyte is reduced

options.label: D
options.text: Fouchet’s test will be strongly positive.

questions.correct_answer: A. Level of 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate is increased.

questions.text: A patient suffering from HIV presents with dyspnoea and productive cough. His HRCT image shows pcrihilar and mid and lower zone bilateral interstitial or ground-glass infiltrate extending from hilar region till surrounding lung. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis

options.label: A
options.text: Increased degradation of collagen due to inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Vasospasm of vasa vasorum leading to death of smooth muscles.

questions.text: A 55 year smoker presents with worsening cough, severe flank pain and hematuria to the emergency room, an emergency ultrasound shows a large renal stone. Serum calcium levels were elevated. Urine examination shows numerous RBC and no casts. The patient underwent lithotripsy for the same. Just before discharge the patient complains of hemoptysis, a chest CT was performed which shows a lesion in the lung. Biopsy of this lesion was taken and is most likely to show which of the following features?

options.label: B
options.text: A malignant lung tumor with keratin Pearls

options.label: C
options.text: A malignant lung tumor with Azzopardi effect

options.label: D
options.text: A benign lung tumor with disorganised tissue.

questions.correct_answer: B. A malignant lung tumor with keratin Pearls

questions.text: A 32-year female presents with repeated episodes of vertigo and inability balance herself occasionally. On examination there is a reduced hearing. She also complains of recurrent headaches. Other clinical examination is insignificant hence a brain imaging was done which is as shown in the image. The patient’s mother was treated for vestibular schwannoma 15 years back.A surgical excision of the lesion was done and histology is as shown in the image. Which of the following is not true about the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: . She might be carrying inherited NF-2 mutation.

options.label: B
options.text: The tumor might worsen during pregnancy.

options.label: C
options.text: The tumor has a schwann cell differentiation.

questions.correct_answer: C. The tumor has a schwann cell differentiation.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive fatigue for last 7 months. The patient has been prescribed multiple iron and vitamin supplements but no improvement is seen during this period. A CBC shows Hematocrit of 25%,Hb 8g/dL, TLC 10,000/cu.mm, platelet count of 1.8lskhs/cu.mm, RBC count of 3.5 million. Iron profile shows Serum iron of 35 m g/dL, serum ferritin of 25 m g/L, total iron binding capacity of 450 m g/dL. Which of the following is the next line of management in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Do bone marrow aspirate and Prussian blue stain.

options.label: B
options.text: Measure ESR, CRP and other chronic inflammatory markers.

options.label: C
options.text: Evaluate for B12 and folic acid levels

questions.text: A 48 female underwent a road traffic accident with severe laceration in both her legs. At admission in emergency BP is 110/80, pulse 95/min, temperature 97F, respiratory rate of 22/min. An emergency protocol initiated and 3 units of whole blood transfuion was made in the next 1 hour. During the third transfusion the physician notes that the patients O2 saturation is reduing and is now at 78%. Her vitals now include BP 100/70, respiratory rate 28/min, chest auscultation reveals bilateral crepts. Which of the following is most likely pathogenesis causing such manifestations?

options.label: A
options.text: Anti HLA antibodies damaging the lung vasculature

options.label: B
options.text: Anti ABO antibodies damaging the recipient’s systemic vasculature

options.label: C
options.text: Anti ABO antibodies from the recipient damaging donor RBC

options.label: D
options.text: Inability of heart to handle the volume being transfused.

questions.correct_answer: A. Anti HLA antibodies damaging the lung vasculature

questions.text: A 46-year-old teacher presented with a 5-month history of profuse diarrhoea despite fasting, and associated abdominal bloating. She complained of increasing fatigue and appeared dehydrated. Investigations: haemoglobin [125 g/L (130–180)], serum sodium [138 mmol/L (137–144)], serum potassium [1.9 mmol/L (3.5–4.9)], serum urea [7.3 mmol/L (2.5–7.0)], serum creatinine [105 ?mol/L (60–110)], plasma viscosity 1.76 mPa/s (1.50–1.72). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old man underwent an OGD for investigation of reflux symptoms. Macroscopically he was found to have an area suggestive of Barretts oesophagus. This was biopsied and his histology report was returned to you. Which of the following histological features best supports the endoscopic diagnosis of Barretts oesophagus with no dysplasia?

options.label: A
options.text: Cardiac-type columnar cells bordering squamous mucosa

options.label: B
options.text: Gastric type columnar mucosa with nuclear pleomorphism in all cells seen

options.label: C
options.text: Gastric-type mucosa with a similarity in nuclear/cytological appearances in the crypt base cells to those at the surface epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Intestinal metaplastic glandular mucosa with adjacent oesophageal ducts

questions.correct_answer: D. Intestinal metaplastic glandular mucosa with adjacent oesophageal ducts

questions.text: A patient presents with hematuria and recent onset hypertension. Urine examination shows 10 RBC per HPF and many RBC casts. A renal biopsy was done and a Silver-stained biopsy section is as shown in the image. An immunofluorescence shows deposits of C3. Which of the following could lead to such a disease?
questions.correct_answer: A. An autoantibody against C3 convertase.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman under surveillance for Barretts oesophagus was found to have high-grade dysplasia in four biopsies at gastroscopy. Repeat gastroscopy and further biopsies confirmed this. The Barrett’s segment appeared uncomplicated macroscopically, and was circumferential and 5 cm in length (Prague C5M5). She was taking a high-dose proton pump inhibitor. She declined surgical intervention. Which of the following is the most appropriate management step?

A 4-year-old girl is having diarrhoea for last 2 years, she has received multiple antibiotics for the same with no respite. She also complains of easy fatigue and not willing to play outdoors. Physical examination shows the child is on 3 rd percentile for height and weight for similar age, there are bitots spots seen in eyes. Peripheral blood examination is as shown in the image. Physical examination of stools shows that they are floating in water. An intestinal biopsy was performed as next investigation. Which of the following is most likely finding on intestinal biopsy?

options.label: B
options.text: PAS positive material in the lamina propria.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented to the gastroenterology outpatient clinic. He is an only child whose father was diagnosed with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer at the age of 40 years, and died of colorectal cancer. No other family history is available. He is well and not complaining of any symptoms. What is the next most appropriate step in his management?

A 35-year-old man was recently diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. He had stopped smoking 6 weeks earlier after smoking for 12 years, and had taken ibuprofen and paracetamol for chronic back pain for the last 6 months. His grandfather had Crohn’s disease; none of his siblings had IBD. He had lived in Cardiff for the past 15 years, working as a solicitor, and he was a vegetarian. Which of the following risk factors most strongly predispose him to developing ulcerative colitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic intake of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) B. Family history of IBD

questions.text: A neonatologist is examining a 2-day old neonate,delivered to a 40 kg mother via full term vaginal delivery. The neonates umbilical cord bleeding is oozing with blood although it had stopped earlier. He draws a sample of blood for coagulation profile and administers2 mg of vitamin K IV injection in addition to a dose of fresh frozen plasma. Two hours later the reports suggest a normal platelet count PT and APTT are elevated, but the bleeding has stopped now. What is the next line of management in this neonate?

options.label: C
options.text: Give oral vitamin K at 2 and 4 weeks.

questions.correct_answer: C. Give oral vitamin K at 2 and 4 weeks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was admitted on the medical take with cardiac-sounding chest pain. She had a body mass index of 34 kg/m2. She suffered from osteoarthritis of both knees and had type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was keen to understand more about obesity and her potential treatment options. Which of the following is the best treatment option for her obesity at this stage?

A 3-year child presents with a testicular mass in left testis. An inguinal orchidectomy was performed. Histological examination of the tumor is as shown, the tumor cells were positive for desmin and myogenin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old man underwent an abdominal ultrasound examination for upper abdominal pain. The report suggested that although the liver architecture was normal and the common bile duct of normal calibre, there was debris in the gallbladder and one large lesion adjacent to the gallbladder wall which may have been either a gallbladder stone or a polyp. Which of the following statements about gallbladder polyps is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Cholecystectomy is recommended for all gallbladder polyps

options.label: B
options.text: In the presence of PSC the malignant potential is increased

options.label: C
options.text: Most commonly these are adenomatous polyps

options.label: D
options.text: Symptomatology does not dictate the need for cholecystectomy

questions.correct_answer: B. In the presence of PSC the malignant potential is increased

questions.text: A 6-year-child has presented to paediatrician with recent onset bed wetting despite the child having achieved bladder control long before. On detailed history the child has an excessive thirst and frequent urination. Urine examination grossly the urine is pale, microscopy is insignificant. Blood examination shows normal blood glucose levels serum sodium is 170mEq/L (normal 135-145). Urine osmolality is 200mOsm/L after injection of antidiuretic hormone the osmolality is 700 m Osm/L. a radiological examination performed as shown in the image. histological examination of this lesions is likely to show?

options.label: A
options.text: Cells with blue cytoplasm and eccentrically located nucleus.

options.label: C
options.text: Neoplastic lymphoid cells with dark hyper chromatic nucleus and scant cytoplasm.

options.label: D
options.text: A tumor with Nesting pattern and salt and pepper chromatin .

questions.correct_answer: B. Neoplastic histiocytes with grooved nuclei.

questions.text: A 26-year-old IV drug abuser has had a high fever for the past 2 days. On exam he has a heart murmur. Echocardiography shows destruction of the aortic valve by large, irregular vegetations. Staphylococcus aureus is cultured from his blood. He develops left upper quadrant pain. Abdominal CT shows a wedge-shaped 1.5 x 3 cm splenic lesion with base on the capsule. The splenic lesion is most likely to result from which of the following cellular abnormalities?
The treatment of hyperlipidemic patients with nicotinic acid (niacin) results in

options.label: B
options.text: Decreases in both plasma cholesterol and TGs

options.label: E
options.text: No change in total choleserol in the plasma

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreases in both plasma cholesterol and TGs

questions.text: In the management of a cardiac arrhythmia, lidocaine is to be administered by way of an IV loading dose. What variable must be known to calculate an appropriate loading dose?

A 30-year-old woman was reviewed in clinic after a recent inpatient stay with cholangitis. She originally presented with jaundice, rigors, and right upper quadrant pain. She was treated with antibiotics, and after an abdominal ultrasound scan which suggested a dilated CBD, she went on to have an ERCP. The ERCP did not reveal stone disease, but showed fusiform dilatation of the CBD. She made a good recovery and was discharged. An MRCP was arranged as an outpatient, which confirmed spindle-like dilatation along the length of the CBD. A diagnosis of choledochal cyst type I was made. What is the most appropriate management for a type I choledochal cyst?

options.label: B
options.text: Sequential scanning with a view to surgical excision if progression occurs

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical excision if complications are problematic

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical excision even if asymptomatic

questions.text: A patient with a supraventricular tachycardia has an atrial rate of 280/min with a ventricular rate of 140/min via a 2:1 AV nodal transmission. After treatment with a drug, the atrial rate slowed to 180/min, but the ventricular rate increased to 180/min! Which of the following drugs was most likely to have been given to this patient?

A 60-year-old man presented to the emergency clinic with painless jaundice. His USS and CT supported a diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma, and biopsies obtained via ERCP confirmed adenocarcinoma. He was keen to have surgical treatment if possible, and was discussed by the upper GI MDT. In the case of a tumour of the head of pancreas, which of the CT findings has the most promising likelihood of cure with surgical intervention?

options.label: B
options.text: Bulky tumour with local lymph nodes

questions.correct_answer: B. Bulky tumour with local lymph nodes

questions.text: A habitual user of a schedule-controlled drug abruptly stops using it. Within 8 h, she becomes anxious, starts to sweat, and gets severe abdominal pain with diarrhea. These symptoms intensify over the next 12 h, during which time she has a runny nose, is lacrimating, and has uncontrollable yawning and intensification of muscle cramping and jerking. Assuming that these are withdrawal symptoms in the patient due to her physical dependence, the drug most likely to be involved is

A 68-year-old woman attended for a gastroscopy having been referred by her GP with anaemia, 4 kg weight loss, and non-specific abdominal discomfort. No melaena had been witnessed, although she reported occasional dark stools. Investigations: haemoglobin 122 g/L (130–180) white cell count 4.6 x 109/L (4.0–11.0) MCV 76 fL (80–96) platelet count 209 x 109/L (150–400) serum ferritin 6 μg/L (15–300) serum folate 2.6 μg/L (2.0–11.0) serum vitamin B12 178 ng/L (160–760) serum C-reactive protein 16 mg/L (< 10) The endoscopic images demonstrated the findings shown in Figure: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

A 42-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with haematemesis and melaena. He had a past medical history of gout and had recently increased his dose of ibuprofen. On examination he was pale with mild epigastric tenderness. His pulse was 124 beats/minute and his blood pressure was 104/79 mmHg. He had an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy demonstrating the lesion shown in picture below Which Forrest classification best describes this lesion?

A 22-year-old Caucasion male presents to general surgery clinic for evaluation and treatment of a left inguinal hernia. During the physical examination, the hernia is identified, but a 3 cm left testicular mass is also noted. It is painless and firm. The patient has not noted it previously. Imaging has confirmed a testicular mass concerning for malignancy. Pending urologic evaluation, a serum β-hCG, Alpha-Fetoprotein (AFP), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) tests are ordered, all of which are significantly elevated above normal limits. Radical orchiectomy will be performed via which incision and will demonstrate which most likely pathology?

A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency room allowing a gunshot wound to the left lower quadrant. He undergoes an exploratory laparotomy at which time a colonic injury is identified, requiring resection of the injured segment and a diverting colostomy. During further assessment a left ureteral transection is noted in midureter. Which of the following considerations is true when performing an ureteroureterostomy?

options.label: A
options.text: A tension- free anastomosis is not required

options.label: B
options.text: Spatulating opposing ends of the ureteral segments can be done selectively.

options.label: C
options.text: Complete the anastomosis with fine, permanent suture is required.

options.label: D
options.text: Placement of a double-J ureteral stent across the anastomosis is recommended.

questions.correct_answer: C. Complete the anastomosis with fine, permanent suture is required.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, with a body mass index o 30 kg/m2, was admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis. She was consented or a laparoscopic appendectomy. She had a previous surgical history o cesarean section. Following the administration of general anesthesia, a curvilinear in paraumbilical skin incision was made. Blunt dissection was carried down to the fascia and the fascia was elevated and incised. Entry into the peritoneal cavity was confirmed visually and a Hasson trocar was inserted into the peritoneal cavity. Following insuniation, a 30°laparoscope was inserted. Upon general laparoscopic examination of the peritoneal cavity, it was apparent that a retroperitoneal hematoma was forming. What is the most commonly injured vessel during trocar placement?

A 50-year-old air skinned, blue-eyed male presents to your office with a skin lesion on the pinna of his right ear concerning or a melanoma. Biopsy determines a superficial spreading melanoma with a depth of 1.1 mm. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide local excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy

options.label: B
options.text: High dose interferon alpha 2b is recommended

options.label: D
options.text: Excisional biopsy and a total parotidectomy

questions.correct_answer: A. Wide local excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy

questions.text: You are consulted on a 35 year-old male, who otherwise healthy, was initially admitted 26 days ago in septic shock secondary to a necrotizing soft tissue infection of the right lower extremity. He required high-dose vasopressors for several days following emergent operative debridement and institution of broad-spectrum antibiotics. He was recovering well in the ICU and was recently extubated. However he developed tachycardia, fever, and leukocytosis. The ICU team calls you to evaluate because they are unable to identify a source of infection. You examine his back and find a pressure sore overlying the right ischial tuberosity approximately 4 × 5 cm in size with a black eschar overlying, expressible malodorous fluid, and surrounding cellulitis. What is the stage of this pressure ulcer?

A 26-year-old male presents with a painless mass in his left axilla that has been present for several months. Upon questioning, the end or ses unexplained low-grade fevers, night sweats, and an unplanned weight loss o 10 lbs over the previous 3 months. On physical exam, he is noted to have a 2 cm firm, rubbery, non-tender mass in the left axilla. Which of the following considerations is true for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: History of fever, chills, night sweats, and weight loss are considered A level symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Physical examination should include thorough exam of all accessible lymph node basins as well as potential sites of a primary malignancy.

options.label: D
options.text: Sexually transmitted diseases can be ruled out by physical exam in younger patients.

questions.correct_answer: C. Physical examination should include thorough exam of all accessible lymph node basins as well as potential sites of a primary malignancy.

questions.text: A patient is prescribed isoniazid prophylactically since another family mem- ber currently has tuberculosis. When the patient ends up getting tuberculosis despite prophylaxis, resistance to isoniazid is suspected. In what way did this resistance likely develop?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased intracellular accumulation of the drug

options.label: B
options.text: Inactivation of the drug via N-acetyltransferases

options.label: D
options.text: Mutations in the gene coding for DNA-dependent RNA polymerase

options.label: E
options.text: Reduced expression of the gene that encodes a catalase

questions.correct_answer: E. Reduced expression of the gene that encodes a catalase

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 31-year-old male presents with a painless bulge in his right groin. Although it does not bother him or limit his daily activities, he notices fluctuation in its size, from being absent when he lies at or a few minutes, to a golf -ball sized mass upon coughing or strenuous exercises. Physical examination confirms the presence of a right inguinal hernia. No abnormalities were noted on the contralateral side. Regarding the management and indications for surgical intervention of asymptomatic inguinal hernias, which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation is not recommended, as the incidence of inguinal hernia strangulation is greater than 10% after 5 years.

options.label: B
options.text: Elective surgical repair is advised for otherwise healthy patients, as procedure is fairly low-risk and post-operative complications are always minor, if any.

options.label: C
options.text: Both watchful waiting and surgical repair are same as treatment options, however most patients will develop symptoms over time and require an operation.

options.label: D
options.text: The type of inguinal hernia, whether direct or indirect, heavily dictates the management approach, as incarceration is at least ten times more often in the case of direct hernias.

questions.correct_answer: C. Both watchful waiting and surgical repair are same as treatment options, however most patients will develop symptoms over time and require an operation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with pharyngitis and fever of 2 days’ duration, and microbiology reveals small, translucent, beta-hemolytic colonies sensi- tive in vitro to bacitracin. Past history includes a severe allergic reaction to amoxicillin when used for an ear infection. The physician needs to treat this infection, but prefers not to use a drug that needs parenteral administration. Which one of the following agents is most likely to be appropriate in terms of both effectiveness and safety?

A 62-year-old man with hypertension was referred to the general surgery clinic for further evaluation of chronic abdominal pain, bloating, and early satiety, which had been worsening over several months. He was previously healthy except for hypertension controlled with metoprolol and a history of inguinal hernia repair. His last screening colonoscopy performed 2 years ago was negative. On review of systems, he endorses significant fatigue. Laboratory results are consistent with mild anemia. An abdominal C scan was obtained for further evaluation and revealed a large tumor of gastric origin (pictured below). The best next step to definitively diagnose this lesion is:

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy with biopsy and peritoneal washings

questions.text: A patient with RA is being treated with ibuprofen, but joint pain and stiff- ness are increasing. His physician prescribes another drug to be used with ibuprofen that may slow progression of the disease. Unfortunately, side effects develop, including dizziness, tinnitus, blurred vision, and pruritus. Ocular examination reveals corneal deposits and slight retinal pigmenta- tion. What is the drug?

A 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, atrial brillation, and obesity presents to the emergency department with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematochezia. Previous operations include a laparoscopic appendectomy. On physical exam the patient appears to be in significant distress due to pain; however, his abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. Laboratory analysis is remarkable or a white blood cell count o 21 × 109/mL and a lactate of 3.5 mmol/L. Abdominal radiography is unremarkable. CT angiography is significant for absence of flow distal to the origin of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). What is the likely etiology for this SMA occlusion?

options.label: B
options.text: Embolic occlusion of the mesenteric circulation

options.label: C
options.text: Acute thrombosis of the mesenteric circulation

questions.correct_answer: B. Embolic occlusion of the mesenteric circulation

questions.text: You are called to the emergency department to evaluate a 25-year-old woman complaining of abdominal pain starting 12 hours prior to presentation. She initially characterized the pain as a periumbilical discomfort, but now it is sharp and localizes to her right lower quadrant. Review of systems is positive or a temperature elevation (measured at 38°C at home), anorexia, and nausea without emesis, and the patient denies diarrhea, melena, and hematochezia. Her past medical history, past surgical history, social history, and family history are all unre-markable. The patient’s last menstrual period was three weeks ago. She does not take any scheduled medications and has no known allergies. Measurement of her vital signs demonstrate a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, blood pressure of 118/74mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%on room air. Physical examination is normal except for loocal tenderness to palpation most prominent at McBurney’s point. What is the most important laboratory test to order for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Prothrombin time (PT ) and partial thrombo-plastin time (aPTT)

questions.text: A 57-year-old, otherwise healthy female presents to your clinic to discuss the results of her recent screening mammogram. She has previously had unremarkable screening mammograms since the age of 40. She has two aunts with breast cancer, and recently heard that her 35-year-old niece was diagnosed with invasive ductal adenocarcinoma. She reports no palpable masses noticed on breast self -exams, no nipple drainage, no breast skin changes, and no other concerning constitutional symptoms. The patient requests counseling on various genetic syndromes, given the young age of her recently diagnosed niece. Which of the following is correctly matched?

options.label: A
options.text: BRCA1—chromosome 13q—increased female and male breast cancer risk.

options.label: B
options.text: BRCA1—chromosome 17q—increased female breast and ovarian cancer risk.

options.label: C
options.text: Li-Fraumeni syndrome—PTEN mutation— increased breast, nervous system, and GI tract cancers.

options.label: D
options.text: Peutz-Jehgers syndrome—KRAF mutation— increased breast and colon cancer, mucocutane- ous lesions.

questions.correct_answer: B. BRCA1—chromosome 17q—increased female breast and ovarian cancer risk.

questions.text: Following an overdose of an over-the-counter drug, a young college student has marked gastrointestinal distress and is lethargic and confused, with an elevated body temperature. Lab analysis of blood reveals: pCO2, ↓ HCO3–, ↓ K+, and an anion gap acidosis. The most likely cause of these signs and symptoms is a toxic dose of

A 42-year-old otherwise healthy female recently underwent core-needle biopsy of a palpable 4 cm left breast mass in the upper outer quadrant that revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. On physical exam she had no further palpable lesions and no palpable lymph nodes. Metastatic work-up was negative. She would like to discuss mastectomy and reconstruction options prior to her surgery. Which of the following is an advantage of autologous tissue reconstruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Better symmetry with the contralateral breast

options.label: D
options.text: Lower potential or the need o blood transfusion when compared with implant reconstruction

questions.correct_answer: A. Better symmetry with the contralateral breast

questions.text: A 43-year-old female is referred to your office by her primary care physician for evaluation of a lesion on thyroid ultrasound? The primary care physician thought the left side of the neck felt fuller than the other and ordered an ultrasound of the neck and lab work. A lesion was seen on the ultrasound and her primary care physician referred her to general surgery for evaluation. The patient states that she feels perfectly well with no loss in weight or hot flashes. She has no family history of cancer or neck irradiation. After performing a thorough physical exam, you feel a fullness in her left neck corresponding with her left thyroid gland but no obvious discrete mass. Her lab work shows a normal chemistry panel and normal thyroid panel. The ultrasound reveals a 0.4 cm circular, smooth, solid, intracapsular lesion . What would be your next step in management or this lesion?

The child is suffering from severe gastrointestinal discomfort and has thrown up twice, each time producing a bloody vomitus. A one-month old Caucasian boy is brought to his primary care provider (PCP) by his parents due to difficulty feeding. This is their first child and they are very concerned. The child has been bottle fed since birth and almost every time he eats he has a bout of emesis. They state the emesis has gotten worse; it has remained non- bilious, but increasingly projectile. The parents have tried changing formulas, but without relief. He continues to show interest in eating, as his PCP watches him vigorously drink from his bottle. On exam the infant’s vitals are normal for his age, and he is afebrile. He is well-appearing, though small for his age. The PCP attempts to do an abdominal exam and thinks he feels a mass in his right upper quadrant,fbut the infant begins to cry, making the exam more difficult What is thought to be the pathogenesis of this syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: A deficiency in neuronal nitric oxide

options.label: D
options.text: Increased testosterone levels in the infant

questions.correct_answer: B. A deficiency in neuronal nitric oxide

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the ER by some of his friends because he “started going crazy” after eating seeds from a plant while “trying to get high.” The boy was incoherent; his skin was hot and dry. You are called to the delivery room to assist in management of the delivery of a child with a known anterior abdominal wall defect and maternal polyhydramnios. Which of the following is the most important aspect regarding the management of this patient?

questions.text: During the annual Memorial Day parade of your home-town, a large explosion occurs along the parade route, with multiple injured persons and fatalities at the scene. questions.text: In an amenorrheic patient who has had pituitary ablation for a craniopharyngioma, which of the following regimens is most likely to result in an ovulatory cycle?

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1 undergoes a triple screen test at 16 weeks of pregnancy to evaluate her risk of having a baby with Down syndrome because she is worried about being of “advanced maternal age.” Her maternal serum AFP level comes back elevated. This patient is extremely concerned and comes into your office to get additional counseling and recommendations. All of the following are true statements that you can tell her except

options.label: A
options.text: An elevated serum AFP level indicates that she is at risk for having a baby with Down syndrome, and you recommend that she undergo a chorionic villus sampling to definitely determine the fetus’s chromosomes

options.label: B
options.text: An ultrasound should be performed to confirm the gestational age of the fetus and rule out any fetal anomalies

options.label: C
options.text: Fetal neural tube defects, multifetal gestations, and fetal abdominal wall defects are all possible etiologies of an elevated MSAFP

options.label: D
options.text: Unexplained elevated MSAFP levels have been associated with poor pregnancy outcome, such as placental abruption, oligohydramnios, or fetal death in utero

questions.correct_answer: A. An elevated serum AFP level indicates that she is at risk for having a baby with Down syndrome, and you recommend that she undergo a chorionic villus sampling to definitely determine the fetus’s chromosomes

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with uterine leiomyomata found on pelvic examination complains of excessive uterine bleeding. Which of the following should be the next step in the management of this patient?

A 20-year-old with an LMP 1 week ago who presents to the emergency room complaining of a 2-day history of increasing abdominal pain. This morning she experienced fever and chills, although she did not take her temperature. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Urinalysis is completely normal. WBC is 18,000. Temperature is 102°F. On physical exam, her abdomen is diffusely tender with rebound. On bimanual exam, bilateral adnexal masses are palpated. The patient is sent to the ultrasound department, and a transvaginal ultrasound demonstrates bilateral tuboovarian abscesses. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

A 55-year-old woman who has been in her usual state of good health notices stiffness in her right knee after kneeling in her garden. This condition worsens during the next 6 months to the point where she finds her right knee to be persistently stiff, painful, and slightly swollen. She visits her physician, who feels the symptoms are consistent with a mild case of arthritis, and he prescribes symptomatic relief. Although this treatment initially helps, she soon finds that her knee becomes more swollen, erythematous, and warm. At another visit, her physician aspirates the knee and orders a Gram stain and culture of the fluid. When the laboratory reports these tests as negative, her physician prescribes a course of steroids. These provided symptomatic relief, but at the conclusion of the treatment, the swelling, erythema, and pain return. Another 3 months have passed, and the physician decides to admit her to the hospital. Additional fluid is collected for stains and culture.
